prior_works.title: Value-Decomposition Networks for Cooperative Multi-Agent Learning
prior_works.authors: Peter Sunehag, Guy Lever, Audrunas Gruslys, Wojciech M. Czarnecki, Max Jaderberg, Simon Schmitt, et al.
prior_works.role: Introduced additive value decomposition (sum of per-agent utilities) as a practical inductive bias for cooperative MARL.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present paper explains, via a non-entanglement condition on the MDP transition kernel, when a VDN-style additive decomposition is theoretically exact and how deviations can be bounded.

prior_works.title: QMIX: Monotonic Value Function Factorisation for Deep Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.authors: Tabish Rashid, Mikayel Samvelyan, Christian Schroeder de Witt, Gregory Farquhar, Jakob Foerster, Shimon Whiteson
prior_works.role: Generalized value factorization with a monotonic mixing network, formalizing the IGM principle linking local and global optima.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By tying exact decomposability to non-entangled transitions, the paper provides an MDP-level explanation for when QMIX’s structural constraint is sufficient and uses the entanglement measure to reason about its approximation error.

prior_works.title: Coordinated Reinforcement Learning
prior_works.authors: Carlos Guestrin, Daphne Koller, Ronald Parr
prior_works.role: Used coordination graphs to decompose joint value/reward into local and pairwise components exploiting sparse interactions.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The Markov entanglement notion formalizes interaction strength in transitions, clarifying when coordination-graph decompositions are exact (non-entangled) versus when coupling induces irreducible error.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Dynamic Programming with Factored Representations
prior_works.authors: Craig Boutilier, Richard Dearden, Moisés Goldszmidt
prior_works.role: Established factored MDPs where states and transitions admit graphical factorization, enabling structured value function approximations.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s if-and-only-if result can be seen as a separability/generalization of factored-transition assumptions, characterizing precisely when additive value decompositions are valid.

prior_works.title: Separability Criterion for Density Matrices
prior_works.role: Introduced the PPT separability test in quantum information, a cornerstone for reasoning about entanglement vs. separability.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work inspires treating an MDP’s transition operator analogously to a bipartite quantum state, motivating the non-entanglement criterion used to certify exact decomposability.

prior_works.title: Quantifying Entanglement
prior_works.authors: Vlatko Vedral, M. B. Plenio, M. A. Rippin, Peter L. Knight
prior_works.role: Proposed axiomatic measures of entanglement and their operational roles, establishing how entanglement can bound performance in information-processing tasks.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper adapts these axiomatic ideas to define a ‘Markov entanglement’ measure for transition kernels and uses it to bound the error of value decomposition in multi-agent MDPs.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—an if-and-only-if characterization that additive value decomposition is valid precisely when the multi-agent MDP’s transition operator is non-entangled—sits at the intersection of two lines of work. From multi-agent reinforcement learning, Value-Decomposition Networks and QMIX established practical and widely used structural biases: summing per-agent utilities and monotonic mixing, respectively. These methods assumed, but did not fully explain, when such decompositions capture the true joint value. Earlier structured control frameworks—Boutilier et al.’s factored MDPs and Guestrin–Koller–Parr’s coordination graphs—showed that exploiting sparse, factored transitions can make decompositions accurate and tractable, hinting that the crux lies in how transitions couple agents.

The paper translates this intuition into a precise operator-level statement by importing separability concepts from quantum information. Peres’ separability criterion anchors the notion that an operator’s lack of entanglement certifies decomposability, which here becomes the non-entanglement of the transition kernel. Building on axiomatic approaches to entanglement measurement (Vedral et al.), the authors define a ‘Markov entanglement’ metric tailored to stochastic operators and prove it upper-bounds the error incurred by additive value approximations. Together, these influences yield a unifying theory: classical MARL decompositions are exact for separable (non-entangled) transition dynamics and degrade gracefully as measured entanglement increases—thereby explaining when VDN/QMIX-like methods succeed and how far they can be pushed in the presence of interaction-induced coupling.
